sn12.18:4.2: Then the wanderer Timbaruka went up to the Buddha,
sn12.18:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn12.18:5.1: “Well, Master Gotama, are pleasure and pain made by oneself?”
sn12.18:5.3: “Then are pleasure and pain made by another?”
sn12.18:5.5: “Well, are pleasure and pain made both both oneself and another?”
sn12.18:5.7: “Then do pleasure and pain arise randomly, not made by oneself or another?”
sn12.18:5.9: “Well, is there no such thing as pleasure and pain?”
sn12.18:5.10: “It’s not that there’s no such thing as pleasure and pain.
sn12.18:5.12: “Then Master Gotama doesn’t know nor see pleasure and pain.”
sn12.18:5.13: “It’s not that I don’t know or see pleasure and pain.
sn12.18:5.14: I do know pleasure and pain,
sn12.18:5.15: I do see pleasure and pain.”
sn12.18:6.1: “Master Gotama, when asked these questions, you say ‘not so’.
sn12.18:6.5: Yet you say that there is such a thing as pleasure and pain.
sn12.18:6.8: And you say that you do know pleasure and pain,
sn12.18:6.9: and you do see pleasure and pain.
sn12.18:6.10: Sir, explain pleasure and pain to me!
sn12.18:6.11: Teach me about pleasure and pain!”
sn12.18:7.1: “Suppose that the feeling and the one who feels it are the same thing. Then for one who has existed since the beginning, pleasure and pain is made by oneself. I don’t say this.
sn12.18:7.2: Suppose that the feeling is one thing and the one who feels it is another. Then for one stricken by feeling, pleasure and pain is made by another. I don’t say this.
sn12.18:7.3: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:
sn12.18:7.5: Choices are a condition for consciousness. …
sn12.18:7.6: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
sn12.18:7.7: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.
sn12.18:7.9: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
sn12.18:8.1: When he said this, the wanderer Timbaruka said to the Buddha:
sn12.18:8.3: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the Dharma, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn12.18:8.4: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
